Award.AwardTitle: Combined analysis of surface wave phase and amplitude data using finite frequency kernals: Towards a detailed mode of attenuation in the upper mantle
Award.AbstractNarration:
Studies of the 3D structure of the Earth usually focus on the speed of wave propagation within the Earth, but the rate at which seismic energy is attenuated is also of fundamental interest. Seismic attenuation operates through thermally activated processes and is therefore a very sensitive indicator of temperature variations within the mantle. Thus, combining wave speed variations with attenuation variations gives a powerful tool for learning about the physical cause of seismic anomalies within the Earth. The fundamental datum for learning about seismic attenuation is the amplitude of seismic waves, but amplitudes are affected by so many things, and intrinsic attenuation is not even the strongest contributor to seismic amplitudes. Consequently, it has proven difficult to get a reliable picture of seismic attenuation within the Earth. We use extremely large datasets of the seismic amplitudes (and phase) of fundamental mode surface waves to address this problem. The approach we use is not new and involves trying to directly estimate the various factors affecting surface wave amplitudes. The new feature of this proposal is to use a more robust theoretical basis for assessing the effects of amplitude anomalies caused by focusing and defocusing effects on the seismic wavefield -- one of the main contributors to surface wave amplitude anomalies. Since phase and amplitude effects are intertwined through the effects of physical dispersion, our research will also provide improved understanding of the dispersion of seismic waves and consequently of the elastic structure of the upper mantle. Our datasets are sufficiently large to also address the effects of anisotropy on surface wave propagation -- in itself an important topic of investigation.

This research focuses on improving our understanding of seismic wave propagation with an emphasis on understanding how seismic energy is attenuated in the Earth. Being able to accurately model the propagation of seismic waves in and on the Earth has many societal implications. We give three examples. Firstly, there is the issue of seismic hazard where being able to accurately model seismic amplitudes after a large earthquake is crucial. Secondly, there is the issue of being able to monitor a nuclear test ban reliably. Being able to locate and estimate the size of seismic events of any kind is critical to this endeavor. Finally, as part of this research, we will also be refining models of the seismic sources of many thousands of earthquakes. Improving our understanding of seismic sources is of obvious intrinsic interest to society.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Seismic surface waves generated by moderate to large earthquakes are recorded around the globe and can be used to determine earth structure in the top few hundred kilometers of the Earth. This project uses an extensive set of seismograms to determine the propagation characteristics (wave speeds and amplitudes) of surface waves (both Rayleigh waves and Love waves) over a period range of 200 to 25 seconds. A novel measurement technique was developed to allow efficient processing of the millions of seismograms involved and resulted in several hundred thousand measurements at each period. These measurements were combined with previously determined group velocity measurements to make a comprehensive dispersion model (wave speed as a function of frequency) for both Love and Rayleigh waves. This model is the subject of a refereed journal publication and the model and datasets that go into its construction are available on the web (see final report). This dispersion model has been used to improve global models of crust and lithosphere structure with a nominal lateral resolution of one degree.

It was rapidly verified that Rayleigh wave dispersion requires the inclusion of "azimuthal anisotropy" (i.e. wave speed variations as a function of propagation direction) into the modeling.  This type of anisotropy is of great interest as it is sensitive to alignment of mineral crystals in the Earth caused by solid-state flow in the mantle and can therefore tell us about the nature of mantle convection. It was also found that the patterns of anisotropy that are recovered depend significantly on the locations of the earthquakes. Experiments allowing locations to vary show that a robust model for the azimuthal anisotropy can be recovered and the resulting locations are much more closely clustered at tectonic plate boundaries. A second refereed journal publication describes these results (see final report).

In the final part of the project, we used the amplitude measurements to determine the laterally varying attenuation characteristics of surface wave propagation. This is a technically intricate problem and requires the modeling of focusing and defocusing effect to be successful. We implemented a finite-frequecy approximation to the theoretical effect of focusing and defocusing and generated new global maps of Rayleigh wave attenuation that are the most reliable and of the highest resolution of any to date. A refereed journal publication has been accepted and contains all the attenuation models as a supplement to the paper (see final report).

This project funded the PhD training of a graduate student who was the first author on all the above papers. Thr first of the papers described above was a co-winner of the Geophysical Journal International Student Paper Award in 2014. The student has now gone on to post-doctoral studies at a first-rate academic institution in the USA. Also, as described above, all models and datasets generated by this project are readily available to the community.
